poem:
The Tigers' Unease

In the whisper  
of Siberian winds,  
night ink drips—  
tigers roam,  
a hunger  
older than fear.

Silent, swift,  
their stripes merge  
with shadows,  
dogs' barks,  
muffled.  
An ice fisher's dream  
shatters  
under stars.

In the forest's breath,  
the world's wild heart  
beats loudly,  
unseen.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘The tigers are hungry’: endangered but deadly, the world’s largest big cat is sowing fear in Siberia’s villages The attacks seemed to come from nowhere. At first, the tigers snatched guard dogs on the edge of villages in Russia’s far east, emerging from the forest at night to prey. Others went for livestock, going after horses and cattle. Then the attacks on people began. In January, an ice fisher was mauled at night and dragged". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
